s17_comment: Could have more specificity - e.g., what determined the magnitude of these physiological responses. And perhaps what 'primarily' determines - there is also substantial inter-individual variability in the response to the same 'amount' of light.

s01_comment: On the basis of the CIE definition, this statement can be agreed. However, it should also be noted that most people perceive wavelengths between approximately 400 nanometres (nm) and 780 nm. The wavelength range between 380 nm and 400 nm is an overlap that cannot be perceived equally by all people. This overlap can also be attributed to the UVA portion (320 nm to 400 nm) due to its effect. For example, the erythema curve (range 280 nm to 400 nm) can be quoted here.
s02_comment: On the basis of the CIE definition, this statement can be agreed. However, it should also be noted that most people perceive wavelengths between approximately 400 nanometres (nm) and 780 nm. The wavelength range between 380 nm and 400 nm is an overlap that cannot be perceived equally by all people. This overlap can also be attributed to the UVA portion (320 nm to 400 nm) due to its effect. For example, the erythema curve (range 280 nm to 400 nm) can be quoted here.
s05_comment: In my opinion, however, it would also be good to put this in relation to the other two wavelength ranges, UV radiation and infrared radiation. This would allow a better classification in the entire spectrum of optical radiation and a sharper definition of daylight.
